Fig. 1 XRD patterns of (1) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (2) Pt/ZSM-5 and (3) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum of Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77 K of (1) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (2) Pt/ZSM-5 and (3) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. (Hollow: adsorption branch, Solid: desorption branch). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM images of (a) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (b) Pt/ZSM-5 and (c) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. TEM images of (d) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (e) Pt/ZSM-5 and (f) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Pt particle size distributions of (a) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (b) Pt/ZSM-5 and (c) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of (1) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (2) Pt/ZSM-5 and (3) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Py-IR spectra of (1) Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, (2) Pt/ZSM-5 and (3) Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Pt 4f and (b) Fe 2p XPS spectra of the Pt/zeolite catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Dependence of n-dodecane reaction rate over as-prepared catalysts on time for n-dodecane dehydrogenation. Graphical abstract Dehydrogenation of n-dodecane to linear mono-dodecene by traditional Pt-Sn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst suffers from low linear mono-dodecene selectivity and catalyst instability due to the surface acidity of γ-Al2O3. In this work, we used Fe-silicalite-1, ZSM-5 and silicalite-1 as supports to disperse Pt for catalyzing n-dodecane dehydrogenation. Various characterization of Pt/zeolite catalysts confirm that metallic Pt donating electrons to Fe3+ in Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst makes Pt nanoparticles anchored at the framework Fe site in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite, which leads to formation of well-dispersed and high stability of Pt nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the acidity of as-prepared catalysts follows the order of Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/silicalite-1. The higher catalytic activity, higher linear mono-dodecene selectivity and superior stability of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst compared to Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts for n-dodecane dehydrogenation is owing to well-dispersed and stable electron-deficient metallic Pt anchored at the Fe site in Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite framework and moderate acidity of Fe-silicalite-1. Keywords Dehydrogenation N-dodecane Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 Selective Stable 1 Introduction Dehydrogenation of linear alkanes to linear mono-alkenes is the essential step in the synthesis of lubricants and surfactants [1]. Pt-based catalyst has been considered as a superior catalyst for alkanes dehydrogenation. The dispersion and stability of Pt nanoparticles at surface of support are the key factors, which essentially affect the catalytic dehydrogenation performance of the Pt catalyst [2,3]. Pt-Sn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has been commercialized for the dehydrogenation of linear alkanes [4]. γ-Al2O3 possesses a large amount of pentacoordinate Al3+ site defects, and these coordinatively unsaturated Al atoms act as anchoring sites to immobilize Pt atoms, and lead to well-dispersed Pt nanoparticles [5]. However, the strong surface acidity of γ-Al2O3 will lead to many undesirable side reactions, such as cracking, isomerization, polymerization and cyclization reactions, thereby inevitably exhibiting lower selectivity to linear mono-olefins, catalyst coking and instability [6]. Therefore, a lot of researchers devoted to develop new types of supports to improve the catalytic performance for linear alkanes dehydrogenation. Support modification and development aims to lower surface acidity as well as maintain a higher Pt dispersion degree. One strategy is to use other polymorphs of Al2O3, such as θ-Al2O3 or α-Al2O3, because they have fewer Brønsted acid sites in comparison to γ- Al2O3, unfortunately, they possess lower surface areas which leads to a lower Pt dispersion [7]. Yet another strategy is to use Zn and Mg to dope the Al2O3 support, because the obtained spinel phase (i.e. MgAl2O4 and ZnAl2O4) is less acidic and thermally more stable relative to γ-Al2O3. MgAl2O4 and ZnAl2O4 supports also restrain the sintering of Pt and maintain a higher Pt dispersion because of a strong metal–support interaction [8–12]. In particular, zeolites have been considered as promising alternative supports for alkanes dehydrogenation catalysts since that their acidity can be easily adjusted and they can anchor small Pt nanoparticles [13,14]. Iglesia and coworkers previously reported that Pt supported on [Fe]ZSM-5 catalyst showed unprecedented activity, selectivity and stability for the dehydrogenation of light alkanes to linear mono-alkenes. They suggested that replacing Al3+ with Fe3+ in the ZSM-5 framework retained exchange sites required for anchoring of Pt precursors, this leads to formation of smaller Pt nanoparticles and well-dispersed Pt clusters. Furthermore, the weaker acidity of [Fe]ZSM-5 compared with [Al]ZSM-5 was responsible for the suppression of side reactions [15]. Further modifications of the Pt/[Fe]ZSM-5 catalyst involving the neutralization of the residual acid sites with Cs after Pt reduction improved the selectivity of the catalyst in the dehydrogenation of n-pentane and n-heptane [16]. Kley and coworkers studied the influence of acid sites on the propene selectivity over Pt-Zn/Na-MCM-22 catalyst for propane dehydrogenation. They demonstrated that reduction of the noble metal of zeolite catalysts by an aqueous sodium borohydride solution produced metallic catalysts with lower acid site concentrations than by reduction with H2, consequently the selectivity of propene increased [17]. Sun and coworkers developed a ligand-protected direct hydrogen reduction method for encapsulating sub-nanometer bimetallic Pt-Zn clusters inside silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite for propane dehydrogenation. Pt-Zn/S-1 catalyst gave a superhigh propylene selectivity of 99.3 % and no obvious deactivation was observed even after 13,000 min [18]. Xu and coworkers developed highly efficient Pt-Sn/Sn-Beta catalyst for propane dehydrogenation, an initial propane conversion of 50 %, high propylene selectivity of 99 % and low deactivation rate of 0.006 h−1 were achieved. They suggested that the highly catalytic performance of Pt-Sn/Sn-Beta is due to the stabilization of Pt clusters onto the isolated Sn sites in the zeolite framework, which leads to high dispersion and good stability of Pt clusters at the surface of Sn-zeolite [19]. Up to now, Pt supported on zeolite catalysts used for dehydrogenation of heavy alkanes, such as n-dodecane which suffers from more severe side reactions than light alkanes has not been reported. The main difference in reaction pathways of larger alkanes is that a significant amount of cyclic compounds can be generated via dehydrocyclization, which leads to serious coking, this is not the case for light alkanes [1]. In this work, we applied Fe-silicalite-1, ZSM-5 and silicalite-1 zeolites which possess different acidity as supports to synthesize Pt-based catalysts for n-dodecane dehydrogenation. The experimental results show that Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 exhibits the highest catalytic activity, selectivity and stability for n-dodecane dehydrogenation. The structure and catalytic performance relationship over these Pt/zeolite catalysts have also been investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst Fe-silicalite-1 was prepared through a hydrothermal method, using Fe(NO3)3∙9H2O as the iron source, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silica source and tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) as the template. An aqueous solution of Fe(NO3)3∙9H2O (0.404 g) was mixed with an aqueous solution of TPAOH (16.28 g) for stirring 1 h followed by adding 20.83 g TEOS, and the total water amount is 27 g. After stirring for 1 h, the mixture was placed in a 100 mL autoclave and crystallization at 170 ℃ for 24 h. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with deionized water 3 times, dried at 80 ℃ overnight and then calcined at 550 ℃ under air atmosphere for 6 h. The obtained sample was H-Fe-silicalite-1. The H-Fe-silicalite-1 was exchanged three times with an aqueous solution of NH4NO3 (1 M) at 60 ℃ for 6 h, and then was centrifugation, washed with deionized water and dried at 80 ℃, ultimately NH4+-Fe-silicalite-1 was obtained. The NH4+-Fe-silicalite-1 was exchanged three times with an aqueous solution of NaNO3 (1 M) at 60 ℃ for 6 h followed by centrifugation, washed with deionized water, dried at 80 ℃ and calcined at 540 ℃ for 5 h. The obtained sample was Na-Fe-silicalite-1 which was denoted as Fe-silicalite-1 for short. Pt cations were introduced by ion exchange [15] with 0.005 M Pt(NH4)4(NO3)2 for 12 h at 60 ℃. The exchanged sample was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 80 ℃ overnight and calcined at 540 ℃ for 6 h. Ultimately, the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst was synthesized. The theoretical Pt content was 0.5 wt%. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst was prepared using a procedure identical to that described for Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst except that using NaAlO2 (0.082 g) as the Al source replaced using ferric nitrate as the iron source. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Pt/silicalite-1 catalyst For preparing Pt/silicalite-1 catalyst, only tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) used as the silica source in the absence of Fe(NO3)3∙9H2O as the iron source. The other synthesized steps were identical to that of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst described above. 2.2 Catalyst testing The catalytic dehydrogenation of n-dodecane was conducted in a fixed bed reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm. Prior to test, 200 mg (60∼80 mesh) catalyst (quartz sand is added to ensure the bed height of 31 mm) was loaded in the middle of the fixed bed reactor and in-situ reduced at 470 ℃ for 2 h under H2 (50 mL/min) atmosphere. Subsequently the catalyst was cooled down to 450 ℃ and n-dodecane was pumped by a plunger metric pump into the reactor. The liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of the n-dodecane was 0.00487 mol/gPt/s and the experiments were performed under atmospheric pressure. After the dehydrogenation reaction, the post-reaction liquid products were collected and analyzed in an Agilent 7890A equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a HP-INOWAX column (30 m × 0.53 mm × 1.0 mm). The n-dodecane conversion (Cd) and linear mono-dodecene (or side product) selectivity (Si) can be calculated according to the following equations: (1) Cd = (1 – Ad) × 100 % (2) Si = (Ai/Atotal products) × 100 % Where Ad and Ai are the peak area percentages of un-reacted n-dodecane and linear mono-dodecene (or side products), respectively. The n-dodecane reaction rate (rr) and product formation rate (rf) can be obtained by Eqs. (3) and (4): (3) rr = Cd × S (4) rf = Cd × Si × S where Cd, Si and S are the n-dodecane conversion, product selectivity and liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV, the unit is mol/gPt/s). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The actual Pt and Fe contents of catalyst were determined by a PerkinElmer OPTIMA 2000DV inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of catalyst was obtained on a Bruker AXS-D8 X-ray diﬀ ;ractometer fitted with Cu K α radiation (λ =1.5406 Å). The relative crystallinity of the zeolites was determined by comparing the (101, 2θ ≈ 7.9°) peak areas of samples with that of the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 sample which was considered to be 100 % crystallinity. Unit cell volume of catalyst was calculated using MDI Jade 5.0 software. N2 physical adsorption desorption isotherm of catalyst was tested on a ASAP 2020 adsorption analyzer at −196 ℃. Prior to test, sample was pretreated at 200 ℃ for 4 h under vacuum. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum of sample was determined on a Hitachi UV-4100 spectrometer from 200 to 800 nm. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of catalyst was obtained by Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscopy. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of catalyst was observed by Hitachi H-7650 transmission electron microscopy. The Pt dispersion of catalyst was analyzed by pulse chemisorption of CO apparatus (Micromeritics Autochem Ⅱ 2920). Typically, the sample (∼100 mg, 40∼60 mesh) was pretreated under Ar gas flow (30 mL/min) at 500 ℃ for 1 h in order to remove the physical adsorbed species. And then the sample was cooled down to 50 ℃. The 0.17 mL pulses of 10 % CO/He were introduced to the reactor, the time between pulses was 3 min. NH3 temperature-programmed-desorption (NH3-TPD) profile of catalyst was tested on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 analyzer equipped with a TCD detector. Typical process of NH3-TPD is as follows: the specimen (∼100 mg) was heated from room temperature to 500 ℃ by a rate of 10 ℃/min in a stream of Ar (60 mL/min) and hold at 500 ℃ for 2 h, and then the specimen was cooled down to 100 ℃ and subjected to 10 wt% NH3/Ar (40 mL/min) for 2 h. After purifying with Ar (60 mL/min) at 100 ℃ for 2 h, the weakly and physically absorbed NH3 on the catalyst was removed. At last, the specimen was heated from 100 ℃ to 800 ℃ with temperature ramp of 10 ℃/min, and then NH3-TPD profile was recorded by TCD detector. The pyridine adsorption Infrared (Py-IR) spectrum of sample was obtained on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. Typically, the process of Py-IR is as follows: Each finely ground sample (∼30 mg) was pressed into a thin wafer with diameter of 1.3 cm, followed by placed into a quartz cell equipped with CaF2 windows. Prior to test, the sample was heated to 400 °C for 1 h under vacuum and then cooled to 200 °C. Pyridine as a probe molecular was exposed to the disk at 200 ℃ for 30 min, and then the sample was evacuated at 200 ℃ for 1 h to remove the physical adsorption species on the surface, ultimately the Py-IR spectrum was recorded. The concentrations of Brøsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid sites of the catalyst can be obtained by Eqs. (6) and (7) based on the integrated absorbance of B and L bands [20]. (6) C (pyridine on B acid sites) = 1.88 IA (B) R2/W (7) C (pyridine on L acid sites) = 1.42 IA (L) R2/W Where C, IA(B), IA(L), R and W are the concentration (mmol/g), integrated absorbance of B band, integrated absorbance of L band, radius of catalyst disk (cm) and weight of disk (mg), respectively. Temperature-programmed-oxidation (TPO) profile of catalyst was tested on AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption instrument combined with online mass spectrometer (MS, QIC 20). Typically, the sample (∼100 mg) was pretreated under Ar gas flow (40 mL/min) at 400 ℃ for 1 h followed by cooled down to 100 ℃, then the gas flow was switched to 5 % O2/Ar and the catalyst was heated from 100 ℃ up to 800 ℃ at 10 ℃/min. The signals of O2 (m/z = 32) and CO2 (m/z = 44) depending of temperature were simultaneously recorded by online MS. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained with an ESCALAB 250 Xi (Thermal Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical electron analyzer and mono Al K α 150 W X-ray source. The XPS spectra were calibrated by setting the sp3 hybrid of the C 1s peak to 284.8 eV. All of the characterization measurements of these catalysts were carried out after reduction of catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations 3.1.1 XRD and UV–vis analysis The Pt loadings of as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts are all around 0.5 wt% and Fe amount of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 sample is ca. 1.1 wt% as determined with ICP-OES as shown in Table 1 . Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts. Diffraction peaks at 7.9°, 8.8° and 22–24° attributed to typical MFI (PDF#44-0003) framework of molecular sieve can be observed for these three Pt/zeolite catalysts, which suggests that Fe-silicalite-1, ZSM-5 and silicalite-1 all present MFI topological structure. [21] In addition, no peak ascribed to Pt species can be detected, this result may come from high dispersion of Pt and lower Pt loading (0.5 wt%). All the samples are highly crystalline, as indicated by the strong intensity of the characteristic peaks and the weak background noises in the XRD patterns. As shown in Table 1, the relative crystallinity of the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (100 %) is similar as to those of Pt/ZSM-5 (92 %) and Pt/silicalite-1 (95 %) samples due to their similar preparation method. Furthermore, due to the difference in the size of Fe relative to Si, volume expansion of the unit cell with incorporation of Fe is one important indicator of successful incorporation of Fe into the framework [22]. The unit cell volume of Fe-silicalite-1 (5393 Å) is significantly bigger than that of silicalite-1 (5360 Å) which is pure silica molecular sieve, which indicates that Fe successfully incorporates into the molecular sieve framework. In order to identify the different forms of Fe species in Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy experiment was conducted on Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite and UV–vis spectrum has been deconvoluted into several subbands to facilitate to determination of different Fe species. In principle, the absorption of UV region (<450 nm) for FexOy materials may be due to O → Fe3+ ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) transitions. The charge transfer occurs from the highest lying O 2p orbitals to the half-occupied Fe 3d orbitals [23]. Subbands around 240 nm and 290 nm are assigned to isolated Fe3+ in tetrahedral and octahedral coordination, respectively. Subbands at 300 < λ < 400 nm arise from oligomeric clusters and subbands > 400 nm are ascribed to large Fe2O3 particles [24]. In the deconvoluted UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum of Fe-silicalite-1 (Fig. 2 ), strong subbands at 216 nm and 274 nm are ascribed to isomorphously incorporated isolated tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated Fe3+ ions in Fe-silicalite-1 framework, respectively. The weaker subbands at 319 nm can be assigned to small oligomeric Fe species as FexOy inside the zeolite pores. No subband above 400 nm can be observed which indicates non-existence of larger Fe2O3 particles in zeolite pores. The percentage of the subbands with respect to the total area of spectrum has been multiplied with the overall Fe content (accurately determined by ICP-OES) to obtain a rough estimate of the percentage of the different Fe species in Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite. The percentage of the area of the subbands at 216, 274 and 319 nm of Fe-silicalite-1 are 28 %, 63 % and 9 %, respectively. And then the corresponding Fe species percentage is as follows: isolated tetrahedrally coordinated Fe3+ ions (0.31 wt%), isolated octahedrally coordinated Fe3+ ions (0.69 wt%), oligomeric Fe species as FexOy inside the zeolite pores (0.10 wt%). In summary, Fe species in Fe-silicalite-1 mainly exist in the form of isomorphously incorporated isolated Fe3+ ions in Fe-silicalite-1, which also indicates that Fe successfully incorporates into the molecular sieve framework. 3.1.2 Surface area and porosity The N2 adsorption and desorption technique was used to evaluate the overall porous structure of as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts, and corresponding results are shown in Fig. 3 . These three isotherms all present a sharply increasing behavior under p/p0 < 0.01 which could be attributed to the typed Ⅰ isotherm, confirming the microporous character of these three catalysts. The detailed texture data determined from N2 adsorption isotherms are summarized in Table 2 . The BET surface area of these three Pt/zeolite catalysts follows the order of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/silicalite-1. More importantly, the external surface area (Sext = 186 m2/g) and mesopore volume (Vmeso = 0.18 cm3/g) of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are obviously higher than those of Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts. Mesopores in zeolite can improve the dispersity of noble metals. Indeed, it is evident that Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 owns the highest Pt dispersion as discussed in the following part. 3.1.3 SEM and TEM studies The particle overall morphologies of catalysts were observed by the SEM microscopy and the images were shown in Fig. 4 (a–c). All of the as-prepared catalysts exhibit uniform “cylinder-like” aggregates, among which the aggregate size of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (∼500 nm) is higher than those of Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1 (∼300 nm). In addition, the exteral surface on aggregate of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 is obviously rougher than those of Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1, which is in line with Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 owning the highest Sext (Table 2). The supported Pt can’t be observed likely due to the low loading amount and ultra-small particle size of Pt. The TEM microscopy was used to observe the dispersion of Pt and confirm the particle size of supported Pt. According to the overview of the TEM images of as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts (Fig. 4d–f), the Pt nanoparticles supported on Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite show uniform nearly spherical particles. However, Pt particles on ZSM-5 and silicalite-1 display irregular shaped particles. Statistical analyses by counting 100 Pt nanoparticles provide the information on Pt particle size distributions (Fig. 5 ) and Pt mean particle size (Table 3 ). As shown in Fig. 5, the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and Pt/ZSM-5 show Pt nanoparticles of 1_5 nm and 4_10 nm, respectively, with a rather homogenerous distribution. Otherwise, Pt particles supported on silicalite-1 are in a wide range of sizes, from 14 nm up to 28 nm. Table 3 shows that the Pt average particle size of as-prepared catalysts ranks as Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (3.5 nm) < Pt/ZSM-5 (7.3 nm) < Pt/silicalite-1 (17.1 nm). The Pt dispersion of the Pt/zeolite catalyst was determined by CO pulse chemisorption and the results are listed in Table 3. It was shown that Pt dispersion degree of Pt/zeolite catalyst decreases with the increase of Pt average particle size, among which Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 exhibits the highest Pt dispersion (26.3 %). The larger Pt nanoparticles on silicalite-1 may due to the weaker interaction between Pt and neutral support silicalite-1 [25]. The catalytic performance for n-dodecane dehydrogenation is related to Pt dispersion, which will be discussed in the catalytic performance part. 3.1.4 Acidity of the catalysts The acidity properties of Pt/zeolite catalysts were obtained by NH3-TPD results. Based on the definition of acidity, the NH3 desorption in the temperature regions of 120_250 ℃, 250_350 ℃ and 350_450 ℃ are regarded as the weak, medium and strong acid sites, respectively [26]. The NH3-TPD profile of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 shown in Fig. 6 (1) displays two peaks in the range of 110_180 ℃ and 180_300 ℃, manifesting that Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 owns weak and medium acid sites. In comparison, two peaks in the region of 110_240 ℃ and 240_450 ℃ can be observed for Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 6(2)), this result indicates that weak, medium and strong acid sites exist on the surface of ZSM-5. There is limited acid site on the surface of silicalite-1 shown in Fig. 6(3), which is usually regarded as the neutral molecular sieve. The temperature of the maximum desorption rate (Tmax) on the TPD curve is not universally comparable characteristics, because it depends on both the nature of the solid sample and the experimental conditions. Otherwise, the activation energy of ammonia desorption from the acid sites represents the nature properties of acid sites of the catalyst. NH3-TPD profile has been deconvoluted into several subpeaks. The Arrhenius plot can be obtained based on the initial desorption rates of subpeak as a function of the desorption temperature, and then the slope of the Arrhenius plot is the activation energy (E a) of ammonia desorption. The E a of ammonia desorption of the first subpeak and the second subpeak of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are 42 kJ/mol and 78 kJ/mol, respectively, which are lower than those of Pt/ZSM-5 (50 kJ/mol and 98 kJ/mol). The lower E a of ammonia desorption implies the weaker interaction of NH3 and acid sites. These results indicate that acidity of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 is weaker than that of Pt/ZSM-5. On the other hand, one can obtain the qualitative properties of acid sites of catalyst by integrating the TPD curve. Integrating the first subpeak and the second subpeak can obtain the amount of weak acid sites and the strong acid sites, respectively. The amount of weak acid sites, strong acid sites as well as total acid sites are shown in Table 4 . The amount of weak, strong and total acid sites on Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are all lower than those of Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst. The type of acid sites for Pt/zeolite catalysts was distinguished by Py-IR and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The band at 1548 cm−1 is the characteristic peak of pyridinium ions, which are adsorbed on the Brønsted (B) acid sites, and while the characteristic peak at 1449 cm−1 is assigned to pyridine coordinately bonded to Lewis (L) acid sites, what’s more, an intense signal at 1490 cm−1 also can be observed, which refers to the resulting complex from B and L sites [20]. The concentration of B and L acid sites on as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts are calculated according to Eqs. (6) and (7) and listed in Table 5 . The amount of total acid sites on as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts ranks the sequence as follows: Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/silicalite-1, which is consistent with NH3-TPD results. The catalytic selectivity for n-dodecane dehydrogenation are closely related to the acidity properties of catalysts, which will be discussed in the catalytic performance part. 3.1.5 XPS analysis Fig. 8 a presents the XPS spectra for the Pt 4f core-level region of Pt/zeolite catalyst. The binding energies (BEs) of 74.7 eV (Pt 4f5/2) and 71.5 eV (Pt 4f7/2) were attributed to Pt° species [27,28]. The BEs of Pt° 4f5/2 and Pt° 4f7/2 of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 shift toward the higher values of 75.1 eV and 71.9 eV compared to Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts, indicating the decrease of electron density of Pt° in the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst. Fig. 8b shows the XPS spectra for the Fe 2p core-level region of Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite and Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst. The binding energies (BEs) of 725.4 eV (Fe 2p1/2) and 712.3 eV (Fe 2p3/2) were ascribed to Fe3+ ions in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite framework [29,30]. In particular, the peak situated at ca. 705 eV attributed to Fe° can’t be observed. The possibility of the reduction of Fe3+ to form Pt-Fe alloys is significantly low on the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst, this may result from while the Fe3+ in the zeolite framework is harder to reduce than typical supported Fe species. It is should be noted that the BEs of Fe3+ 2p1/2 and Fe3+ 2p3/2 of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are 0.4 eV lower than those of unsupported Fe-silicalite-1. Combined with Pt 4f and Fe 2p XPS results indicates that metallic Pt donate electrons to Fe3+ in Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst, resulting in the decrease in electron density on Pt° and increase in electron density on Fe3+. This electronic interaction between metallic Pt and framework Fe3+ ions makes Pt nanoparticles anchored at the Fe site in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite framework, which leads to formation of well-dispersed and high stability of Pt nanoparticles. Furthermore, the electron-deficient property of metallic Pt° in the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst is may responsible for the high linear mono-dodecene selectivity for n-dodecane dehydrogenation, which will be discussed in the catalytic performance part. 3.2 Catalytic performance for n-dodecane dehydrogenation 3.2.1 Catalytic activity for n-dodecane dehydrogenation The n-dodecane reaction rate over Pt/zeolite catalyst at 450 ℃ during contact with reactants for 14 h is presented in Fig. 9 . For these three catalysts, n-dodecane reaction rates initially decrease sharply and then more slowly with time on stream. The n-dodecane reaction rate over as-prepared catalyst during 14 h ranks the order as follows: Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/silicalite-1, the initial reaction rate over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (rr =0.0028 mol/gPt/s) is 1.12 and 5.6 times higher than those over Pt/ZSM-5 (rr =0.0025 mol/gPt/s) and Pt/silicalite-1 (rr =0.0005 mol/gPt/s), which is in line with the results of the sequence of Pt dispersion over Pt/zeolite catalyst. The higher Pt dispersion corresponding to the higher active sites amount brings about the higher reaction rate (catalytic activity). The limited catalytic activity for n-dodecane dehydrogenation over Pt/silicalite-1 comes from poor Pt dispersion resulting from the weaker interaction between Pt particles and neutral support silicalite-1. 3.2.2 Catalytic selectivity for n-dodecane dehydrogenation Because of the limited catalytic activity for n-dodecane dehydrogenation over Pt/silicalite-1 under the LHSV of 0.00487 mol/gPt/s, Fig. 10 only compares the desired and side products formation rates over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts under the LHSV of 0.00487 mol/gPt/s. For both these two catalysts, all products formation rates initially decrease sharply and then more gradually with time on stream until the formation rates achieve constant after 12 h. The desired product linear mono-dodecene formation rates over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are obviously higher than those over Pt/ZSM-5 during reaction time of 14 h, for example, the initial linear mono-dodecene formation rate over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (rf =0.0021 mol/gPt/s) is 2 times higher than that over Pt/ZSM-5 (rf =0.0010 mol/gPt/s), meanwhile, the final linear mono-dodecene formation rate over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (rf =0.0014 mol/gPt/s) is ca. 2.3 times higher than that over Pt/ZSM-5 (rf =0.0006 mol/gPt/s). Otherwise, the aromatics and light alkanes (C5_C11) formation rates over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are evidently slower than those over Pt/ZSM-5. These results indicate that the linear mono-dodecene selectivity over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 is obviously superior to that over Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst. Fig. 11 compares the product selectivity of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1, Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts at the same n-dodecane conversion of 55 % which can be achieved under the different LHSV. Linear mono-dodecene selectivity follows the order of Pt/Fe-silicalit-1 > Pt/silicalte-1 > Pt/ZSM-5. Meanwhile, the aromatics and C5_C11 selectivity rank the order as follows: Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/silicalite-1 > Pt/Fe-silicalite-1. According to XPS results, metallic Pt donating electrons to Fe3+ in the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst makes metallic Pt more electron-deficient compared to Pt/silicalite-1 and Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts. Electron-deficient metallic Pt facilitates the CH activation to form linear mono-dodecene. In addition, according to the NH3-TPD and Py-IR results, the acidity and acid sites amount of Pt/ZSM-5 are both higher than those of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and Pt/silicalite-1. Therefore, Pt/ZSM-5 lead to give higher rates of acid-catalyzed cracking, alkene oligomerization and cyclization reactions, and consequently higher selectivity of lighter alkanes, aromatics and other side-products [15,31]. In summary, the cooperation of electron-deficient metallic Pt and weaker acidity of Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite in Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst is responsible for the high linear mono-dodecene selectivity. 3.2.3 Catalyst stability The deactivation rate constant kd is defined as follows: (8) l n 1 - X A X A = k d t + l n [ 1 - X A o X A o ] where XA0 and XA are the initial and final (reaction for 14 h) conversions of n-dodecane. Mean catalyst life (τ) is defined as the reciprocal of the deactivation rate constant [15]. Deactivation rate constants of 0.034 h−1 on Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and 0.111 h−1 on Pt/ZSM-5, and the mean catalyst life (τ) of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and Pt/ZSM-5 are 29.4 h and 9 h, respectively. These results indicate that Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst is more stable than Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst. The coke formation during the successive experiment over the Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts were analyzed by TPO. Fig. 12 presents the TPO profiles of catalysts after used for 14 h. The first and second peak temperatures of CO2 over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are ca. 400 ℃ and 520 ℃, respectively, which are 50 ℃ and 80 ℃ lower than those of Pt/ZSM-5 (450 ℃ and 600 ℃, respectively), these results indicate that the ratio of C to H (C/H) of carbonaceous deposit on Fe-silicalite-1 is lower than that on ZSM-5. The integral peak area of TPO profiles can be as a rough estimate of the coke weight in catalyst. The total integral peak areas of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 and Pt/ZSM-5 are 1.63 × 10−7 and 2.27 × 10−7, respectively, these results indicate that Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst has more coke formation than Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst. Coke formation mainly comes from the further dehydrogenation, polymerization and cyclization side reactions. Therefore, we suggest that the suppression of side reaction over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst leads to decreased coke formation and increased catalyst life time in comparison to Pt/ZSM-5. Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst used previously for n-dodecane dehydrogenation was treated in O2 at 600 ℃ for 2 h. Then, dehydrogenation was carried out on this regenerated catalyst for 14 h. Fig. 13 shows that these milder treatments restore linear mono-dodecene formation rate. Linear mono-dodecene formation rates over regenerated Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst are similar to those of fresh catalyst. The characterization of regenerated Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst were also carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 14 . The molecular sieve Fe-silicalite-1 support still maintains MFI topological structure after regenerated treatment (Fig. 14a). Statistical analyses by counting 100 Pt nanoparticles provide the information on Pt particle size distributions of spent catalyst (Fig. 14c), and Pt mean particle size of regenerated catalyst is 3.7 nm, which is no significantly increase in comparison to fresh catalyst (3.5 nm). This result indicates that the stabilization of Pt nanoparticles onto the Fe sites in the zeolite framework, which leads to good stability of Pt particles at the surface of Fe-silicalite-1. In addition, this result manifests that the deactivation of catalyst (Fig. 9) is owing to the coke formation on the surface of catalyst rather than the sintering of Pt nanoparticle. Coke formation mainly comes from the further dehydrogenation, polymerization and cyclization side-reactions catalyzed by acid sites. Therefore, reaction rates initially decrease sharply and then more slowly with time on stream, apparently because concentrations of acid sites also decreased as deactivation occurred which are covered by the coke. 4 Conclusion In summary, the hetero-atom molecular sieve Fe-silicalite-1 was successfully synthesized through the hydrothermal method. XRD and UV–vis results indicate that Fe successfully incorporates into the molecular sieve framework. We used Fe-silicalite-1, ZSM-5 and silicalite-1 as supports to disperse Pt for n-dodecane dehydrogenation. XRD, N2 physical absorption, SEM, HRTEM, NH3-TPD, Py-IR and XPS techniques execute on these Pt/zeolite catalysts confirm that metallic Pt donating electrons to Fe3+ in Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst makes Pt nanoparticles anchored at the framework Fe site in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite, which leads to formation of well-dispersed and high stability of Pt nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the acidity and acid sites amount on as-prepared Pt/zeolite catalysts follow the order of Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/silicalite-1. The n-dodecane initial reaction rate over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 (rr =0.0028 mol/gPt/s) is 1.12 and 5.6 times higher than those over Pt/ZSM-5 (rr =0.0025 mol/gPt/s) and Pt/silicalite-1 (rr =0.0005 mol/gPt/s). The excellent catalytic activity of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 is due to well-dispersed Pt nanoparticles on Fe-silicalite-1 surface. Moreover, linear mono-dodecene selectivity follows the order of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/silicalite-1 > Pt/ZSM-5, this result comes from the cooperation of electron-deficient metallic Pt and weaker acidity of Fe-silicalite-1. Lower coke formation on the surface of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst compared to Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst is because of the suppression of acid-catalyzed further dehydrogenation, polymerization and cyclization side-reactions. The outstanding regenerability of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 results from the stabilization of Pt nanoparticles onto the Fe sites in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite framework. In a conclusion, the excellent catalytic activity, selectivity and stability of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 are mainly owing to well-dispersed and highly stable electron-deficient metallic Pt nanoparticles anchored at Fe3+ site in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite framework and moderate acidity of Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite. This superior catalytic activity, selectivity and stability for n-dodecane dehydrogenation over Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst imply that it may be a promising catalyst for practical application and may be suitable for the longer chain alkanes (i.e. octodecane) dehydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Dehydrogenation of n-dodecane to linear mono-dodecene by traditional Pt-Sn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst suffers from low linear mono-dodecene selectivity and catalyst instability due to the surface acidity of γ-Al2O3. In this work, we used Fe-silicalite-1, ZSM-5 and silicalite-1 as supports to disperse Pt for catalyzing n-dodecane dehydrogenation. Various characterization of Pt/zeolite catalysts confirm that metallic Pt donating electrons to Fe3+ in Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst makes Pt nanoparticles anchored at the framework Fe site in the Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite, which leads to formation of well-dispersed and high stability of Pt nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the acidity of as-prepared catalysts follows the order of Pt/ZSM-5 > Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 > Pt/silicalite-1. The higher catalytic activity, higher linear mono-dodecene selectivity and superior stability of Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst compared to Pt/ZSM-5 and Pt/silicalite-1 catalysts for n-dodecane dehydrogenation is owing to well-dispersed and stable electron-deficient metallic Pt anchored at the Fe site in Fe-silicalite-1 zeolite framework and moderate acidity of Fe-silicalite-1.
coredata.dc:title: Active, selective and stable Pt/Fe-silicalite-1 catalyst for dehydrogenation of n-dodecane to linear mono-dodecene
